item.title: Massachusetts Church Keeps Anti-ICE Nativity Scene, Defying Diocese Leaders
item.description: The Christmas display, which replaces Jesus, Mary and Joseph with a sign saying “ICE Was Here,” has drawn criticism from Catholic leaders and immigration officials.
item.dc:creator: Jenna Russell
item.media:credit: Brian Snyder/Reuters
item.media:description: A Nativity scene at St. Susanna Parish in Dedham, Mass., displays a sign reading “ICE Was Here” in the spot where Jesus, Mary and Joseph would normally be.

item.title: DeSantis Designates CAIR, Muslim Advocacy Group, a ‘Terrorist Organization’
item.description: The executive order from the Florida governor came after another Republican governor, Greg Abbott of Texas, issued a similar declaration last month.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Ron DeSantis’s order comes after another Republican governor, Greg Abbott of Texas, issued a similar declaration against the Council on American-Islamic Relations.

item.title: Trump Again Threatens Tariffs on Mexico Over Long-Running Water Dispute
item.description: The threat is the latest aggressive action that President Trump has taken against America’s biggest trading partners.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Las Vírgenes dam in the Mexican state of Chihuahua, which borders Texas and New Mexico.

item.title: Trump Insists Tariffs Will Buoy the Economy and Ease Cost Concerns
item.description: The president rolled out a $12 billion bailout for farmers as he makes the case that his policy is working — or will soon.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The president announced $12 billion in bailout money for America’s farmers who have been battered in large part by his trade policies.

item.title: Why Democratic Governors Argue They Are the Party’s Best Shot for 2028
item.description: A long list of people could test that theory, though governors have struggled to make the leap to presidential nominations in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Mark Schiefelbein/Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan.

item.title: A Frustrated Congress Pushes the Pentagon to Produce Its Boat Strike Orders
item.description: In a sign of bipartisan frustration with the Defense Department, the final defense policy bill aims to compel the Pentagon to share execute orders and video documentation.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth has posted edited footage of the strikes on social media, but has so far refused to share the full video with lawmakers.

item.title: G.O.P. Senators Push Health Care Options as Vote Looms
item.description: The Senate is set to vote later this week on a three-year extension of Affordable Care Act subsidies that Republicans oppose. The G.O.P. has yet to coalesce around an alternative.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Bernie Moreno, along with Senator Susan Collins, has proposed a measure to extend Affordable Care Act tax breaks for two years.

item.title: Trump Backtracks on Releasing Video of Boat Strike
item.description: The president said he would defer to his defense secretary, Pete Hegseth, on whether to release a video showing a follow-up attack that killed survivors of a Sept. 2 strike on an alleged drug smuggling boat.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said last week that “we’d certainly release, no problem,” speaking of a video of a U.S. military strike that killed two people hanging on to the remnants of a suspected drug-smuggling boat.

item.title: Clerk in Murdaugh Trial Is Sentenced to Probation for Perjury and Other Charges
item.description: Becky Hill helped manage the 2023 trial in which Alex Murdaugh was convicted of murdering his wife and younger son.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Jeffrey Collins/Associated Press
item.media:description: Becky Hill, the former clerk of courts in Colleton County, S.C., in court on Monday. She had been accused of perjury, misuse of public funds and sharing court information under court seal with a reporter.

item.title: University of Oklahoma Removes a Teacher It Says Urged Students to Protest
item.description: The protest was over the removal of another instructor, who gave a failing grade on a paper about gender that relied on the Bible as its main source.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Sue Ogrocki/Associated Press
item.media:description: The University of Oklahoma campus in Norman.

item.title: Cora Weiss, Lifelong Champion of Social Justice, Dies at 91
item.description: With a group called Women Strike for Peace, she helped organize demonstrations against the Vietnam War and nuclear weapons. “We managed to get things done,” she said.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Schachar
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:credit: Ron Frehm/Associated Press
item.media:description: Cora Weiss at a news conference in New York City in 1972 with David Dellinger, center, the co-chairman of the Committee of Liaison with Families of Servicemen Detained in North Vietnam, and the Rev. William Sloan Coffin Jr., a Yale chaplain.

item.title: FBI Agents Sue Patel After Being Fired Over Kneeling at George Floyd Protest
item.description: A five-year-old photo of agents kneeling at a D.C. protest after George Floyd’s killing led to the firing of about 16 agents.
item.dc:creator: Devlin Barrett
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Patel decided to fire the agents before the bureau’s Office of Professional Responsibility made their decision following an internal investigation.

item.title: Trump Plans $12 Billion Bailout to Aid Farmers Hit by Tariffs
item.description: The federal aid comes after China boycotted American farm products in retaliation for U.S. tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport, Kevin Draper and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: The money for farmers will come mostly from the Agriculture Department’s Farmer Bridge Assistance program.

item.title: At a Democratic Governors Event, Hope, Nerves and Buzz for the Midterms and 2028 Election
item.description: At an annual event for Democratic governors, optimism about next year overshadowed the search for a long-term vision. As Gretchen Whitmer put it, adding an expletive: “Let’s go!”
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer, Katie Glueck and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Isaac Ritchey/The Grand Rapids Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Gov. Gretchen Whitmer of Michigan, the new vice chair of the Democratic Governors Association, in Grand Rapids this summer. Asked this weekend in Phoenix if she planned to run for president, she shot back, “Who knows?”

item.title: Supreme Court’s Conservatives Have Already Narrowed the 1935 Precedent
item.description: Several conservative justices have indicated their willingness to strengthen the president’s power to fire independent agency leaders.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Chief Justice John Roberts, bottom right, wrote in a 2010 opinion that the president’s power generally includes “the authority to remove those who assist him in carrying out his duties.”

item.title: Trump Promises Executive Order to Block State AI Regulations
item.description: In a Truth Social post, the president said he would sign an order that would eliminate a patchwork of state laws that have emerged in recent years.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump said he would issue an executive order this week to curb state laws on artificial intelligence.

item.title: What will the court’s ruling mean for the Federal Reserve Board?
item.description: The justices have indicated that they will try to find a way to protect the independence of the Fed, even as they let presidents remove leaders of other agencies.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Caroline Gutman for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump has mused about trying to fire Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, but he has not followed through.

item.title: A Scholar’s ‘Bombshell’ Questioned Trump’s Power to Fire Officials
item.description: Caleb E. Nelson, a leading originalist law professor, challenged the conventional wisdom of the “unitary executive theory” in an article that was debated in the parties’ briefs ahead of Monday’s arguments.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court in Washington, D.C.

item.title: The early Federal Trade Commission fielded complaints over cigars, soap and even nose shapers.
item.description: Along with weighty antitrust cases, the early years of the Federal Trade Commission featured disputes about everyday products.
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:description: Among the disputes handled by the Federal Trade Commission during the early 1930s: a complaint over an advertisement for a nose shaper, a strap-on beauty gadget that claimed to reshape the wearer’s nose, according to a review of the Library of Congress archives.

item.title: Who are the lawyers arguing the F.T.C. case?
item.dc:creator: Abbie VanSickle
item.media:credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images
item.media:description: Dean John Sauer, U.S. solicitor general, testifies during his confirmation hearing before the Senate Judiciary Committee, on Capitol Hill, in February.

item.title: What Is the Federal Trade Commission?
item.description: The agency’s first role is to enforce consumer protection laws.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal Trade Commission’s first role is to enforce consumer protection law.

item.title: There are other cases that will test presidential power at the court.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump announcing tariffs at the White House in April.

item.title: These Independent Agencies Could Be Affected by a Supreme Court Case
item.description: Court filings identify more than two-dozen quasi-independent boards and commissions that could be affected by a Supreme Court ruling in President Trump’s favor.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board
United States Commission on Civil Rights
Occupational Safety and Health Review Commission
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal Trade Commission headquarters in Washington.

item.title: Jasmine Crockett Enters U.S. Senate Race in Texas, Reshaping Democratic Primary
item.description: The announcement by the congresswoman, a rising star in the party, came hours after another prominent candidate, Colin Allred, dropped out.
item.dc:creator: J. David Goodman
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times

item.title: Does Trump need a reason to fire leaders of independent agencies?
item.description: Scores of federal laws limit the president’s ability to fire officials like members of the Federal Trade Commission and governors of the Federal Reserve Board.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Moriah Ratner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rebecca Kelly Slaughter, a Democrat who has served on the Federal Trade Commission, at her home.

item.title: Trump Says Netflix Takeover of Warner Bros. ‘Could Be a Problem’
item.description: The fate of the blockbuster Hollywood deal is in the hands of federal regulators.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times

item.title: Who Is Rebecca Slaughter?
item.description: Ms. Slaughter, a Democratic member of the Federal Trade Commission, sued President Trump after he fired her because she did not align with his agenda.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Moriah Ratner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rebecca Slaughter at her home in Maryland last week.

item.title: Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow

item.title: Must the Military Disobey Unlawful Orders? Pam Bondi Has Said Yes.
item.description: As a lawyer for a conservative think tank, Ms. Bondi, now the attorney general, filed a Supreme Court brief last year saying service members who followed such orders were committing crimes.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Attorney General Pam Bondi and Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth at the White House last month.

item.title: New Orleans Restaurants Feel Squeezed as Border Patrol Sweeps In
item.description: Ripple effects from a federal crackdown illustrate how heavily the city’s robust dining scene depends both directly and indirectly on immigrant workers.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Sims and Allison McCann
item.media:credit: Kathleen Flynn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tourists crowded Cafe du Monde in New Orleans on Saturday. Many diners in the city were unaware of the role of immigrant workers in local restaurants.

item.title: Supreme Court Seems Poised to Give Trump More Power to Fire Independent Officials
item.description: A ruling in the president’s favor in the case, which deals with his attempt to remove a member of the Federal Trade Commission, would be a major expansion of presidential authority.
item.dc:creator: Ann E. Marimow
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monday’s case presented the first opportunity for the Supreme Court to issue a conclusive ruling on the underlying legal questions of President Trump’s firings.

item.title: Miami Hasn’t Had a Democratic Mayor in Almost 30 Years. Is That About to Change?
item.description: Democrats see their voters energized in a county that President Trump won. Republicans fear the runoff could add to recent losses.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei
item.media:credit: Eva Marie Uzcategui for The New York Times, Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Republican Emilio T. Gonzalez and Democrat Eileen Higgins will compete for the Miami mayor’s office in a runoff election on Tuesday Dec. 8.
